note.value: These folios preserve two sections of text (John 6:68-7:31 and 8:53-9:23), with an extensive gap between them (John 7:31-8:52). The missing text would have occupied about 18 columns (9 sides, i.e. 4 folios + 1 side). Codicologically more likely is the exclusion of the “Pericope Adulterae” (7:53-8:11). In that case, the missing text would have occupied about 16 columns (8 sides, i.e. 4 folios.). These four lost folios were the two central bifolios of the quire (if it was a quaternion)

Bibliography: R. L. Bensly, J. R. Harris, and F. C. Burkitt, The Four Gospels in Syriac Transcribed from the Sinaitic Palimpsest (Cambridge, 1894), p. xvi ; Α. S. Lewis, Select Narratives of Holy Women: From the Syro-Antiochene or Sinai palimpsest as written above the old Syriac Gospels by John Stylite, of Beth-mari-qanūn in A.D. 778, I, Syriac text (London, 1900), pp. 45-46 ; A. Hjelt (ed.), Syrus sinaiticus, Helsingfors 1930, p. 15 ; C. Guignard, “0323: A Forgotten 4th or 5th Century Greek Fragment of the Gospel of John in the Syrus Sinaiticus,” Novum Testamentum 57 (2015), pp. 311-319
